importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the sexual assault at Gettysburg College occurred.
The year when Ian Cleary sent the Facebook message stating 'So I raped you' to Shannon Keeler.
The year when Shannon Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story highlighting prosecutorial reluctance in campus sexual assault cases.
The date Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy-related charge, which led to his eventual extradition.
The date of the sentencing hearing where Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Keeler renewed her efforts with police and prosecutors after noticing the Facebook message, and when Cleary was eventually extradited from France.
The timeframe in which Cleary sent the message and when the case moved forward after Keeler's renewed advocacy.

keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 was sentenced to two to four years in prison after sending a Facebook message admitting guilt.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, spent over a decade pursuing justice, highlighting systemic failures in prosecuting campus sexual assaults.
The case underscores the difficulty in tracking individuals involved in campus crimes, especially when they go overseas or disappear from public records.
The victim's public advocacy, including sharing her story with the AP in 2021, played a critical role in reactivating the case and leading to Cleary's extradition.
The judge considered Cleary's guilty plea, remorse, and mental health history, resulting in a sentence below standard guidelines.
The message 'So I raped you' was sent as part of a 12-step program, indicating Cleary’s attempt at atonement, though it retraumatized the victim.

namedEntities.name: Shannon Keeler
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The victim of the 2013 sexual assault at Gettysburg College; she initiated legal action and publicly advocated for justice, leading to the case being pursued again after 12 years.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Shannon Keeler is central to the article as the survivor who pursued prosecution for over a decade, highlighting systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases and the personal toll of delayed justice.

namedEntities.name: Ian Cleary
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The man who sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler in 2013 and later sent a Facebook message admitting guilt.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cleary is the central figure in the article; his actions, including the message and eventual extradition, represent a rare case where a long-delayed prosecution occurred due to public advocacy and international tracking.

namedEntities.name: Gettysburg College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The college in Pennsylvania where the sexual assault occurred in 2013.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the assault and the institution where the victim was a student, illustrating the challenges of prosecuting campus sexual violence within university systems.

namedEntities.name: France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country where Ian Cleary was detained in 2024 on a vagrancy charge, leading to his extradition to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: France served as a key location in the case, showing how international jurisdiction and travel complicate the pursuit of justice in sexual assault cases.

namedEntities.name: Metz, France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The specific city in France where Cleary was detained on a vagrancy charge.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Metz is the location of Cleary’s arrest that ultimately led to his extradition, illustrating the role of cross-border legal systems in tracking offenders.

namedEntities.name: Senior Judge Kevin Hess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judge who sentenced Ian Cleary to two to four years in prison.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Judge Hess delivered the sentencing, emphasizing the impact of remorse and mental health on sentencing, and framed the case as a moral and societal issue.

namedEntities.name: Andrea Levy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Shannon Keeler’s lawyer who commented on the sentencing outcome.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Levy represents the legal advocacy side of the case and provided context about the public’s expectations and the outcome’s significance.

namedEntities.name: Brian Sinnett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Adams County District Attorney who expressed doubt about Cleary’s ability to evade justice.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sinnett’s role highlights the institutional challenges in prosecuting cases where suspects are absent or elusive.

namedEntities.name: John Abom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cleary’s defense attorney who claimed Cleary was homeless and unaware of the charges.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Abom’s arguments reflect a common defense strategy in cases involving mental health and homelessness, and underscore the complexity of proving intent or awareness.

namedEntities.name: Tesla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The company where Ian Cleary worked after graduating from college.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tesla represents Cleary’s career trajectory post-assault, showing how he moved from a college setting to a high-profile tech industry role.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary, who sexually assaulted a college student, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013, was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after being extradited from France. The assault had gone without prosecution for nearly a decade, with Keeler’s efforts to pursue justice being delayed by institutional reluctance and the destruction of critical evidence. Cleary sent a Facebook message in 2019 stating 'So I raped you,' which reignited Keeler’s pursuit of justice. After a three-year search and his arrest in Metz, France, on a vagrancy charge, Cleary pleaded guilty and expressed remorse. The judge, Senior Judge Kevin Hess, considered Cleary’s mental health history and remorse, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines. The case highlights systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecutions and the power of survivor advocacy in achieving accountability.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After Facebook Message Admitting Sex Assault, 12 Years After Crime
